importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update reflects the current state of the federal government shutdown, which directly impacts the availability of food stamp benefits for millions of Americans in November.
The federal government shutdown began on October 1, 2025, leading to the immediate threat of food stamp program interruptions, as funding lapses disrupt the delivery of benefits.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The USDA reported that the food stamp program will run out of money in two weeks, creating an urgent timeframe for federal action to prevent benefit suspensions in November.
Millions of Americans are at risk of losing SNAP benefits in November due to the shutdown, highlighting a critical period of vulnerability in the nation’s food assistance system.

keyTakeAways: The Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), commonly known as food stamps, is at risk of depleting its funds in November 2025 due to the federal government shutdown.

The USDA has informed states that full benefits cannot be paid in November without additional funding, and 17 states have suspended new food stamp applications due to the inability to issue partial payments.
The Trump administration has not committed to covering the shortfall, and officials have blamed Democrats for obstructing bipartisan negotiations on spending legislation.
A $6 billion contingency fund is available, but it is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits.
New York Governor Kathy Hochul criticized the administration for halting benefits, calling it a deliberate and harmful action that undermines vulnerable families.
The food stamp program is the second major nutrition assistance program at risk, after WIC, which was temporarily supported by a $300 million shift in tariff revenue.
Advocacy groups emphasize that November is especially critical due to the approaching Thanksgiving holiday, and food pantries are already strained.
The Trump administration has previously intervened to preserve benefits in past shutdowns, raising questions about whether it will do so again.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the author of the article, providing the reporting and context that informs readers about the food stamp crisis during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a key federal official who publicly criticized Democrats and announced that SNAP funding will be depleted in two weeks, directly affecting public policy decisions.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly criticized the Trump administration for halting SNAP benefits, highlighting the human impact on vulnerable families and the political consequences of the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: USDA (U.S. Department of Agriculture)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It oversees the SNAP program and has announced that it lacks sufficient funds to pay full benefits in November, directly affecting millions of Americans.

namedEntities.name: SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the primary food aid program for low-income Americans, and its suspension would create widespread food insecurity, especially around Thanksgiving.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Women, Infants, and Children)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides nutrition support to pregnant women, new mothers, and young children and was previously kept afloat by tariff revenue, but that funding is insufficient for SNAP.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare premium subsidies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Its expiration is a point of political contention, with Democrats arguing Republicans blocked negotiations on funding it, contributing to the broader spending impasse.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is responsible for managing the federal response to the shutdown and has chosen not to allocate funds for SNAP, instead blaming Democrats for the impasse.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are accused of prioritizing political agendas over food security, and are at odds with Republicans over spending negotiations that could resolve the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Republicans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are accused of being unwilling to negotiate spending deals, contributing to the shutdown and the current food stamp funding crisis.

namedEntities.name: Tariff revenue
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was redirected to keep WIC operational, but is insufficient to cover the full cost of SNAP benefits in November.

namedEntities.name: Thanksgiving
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It creates heightened demand for food, making the risk of benefit loss in November especially critical for food-insecure families.

namedEntities.name: Food Research & Action Center
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It emphasizes that SNAP is essential for food security, especially before Thanksgiving, and calls for urgent federal action.

namedEntities.name: Center on Budget and Policy Priorities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It argues that households in need should not be left behind in the shutdown, echoing broader concerns about social safety net protection.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As the federal government shutdown continues through October 2025, the U.S. Department of Agriculture warns that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), or food stamps, will run out of funds in two weeks, threatening to leave millions of low-income Americans without food assistance in November. The Trump administration has not committed to funding the program and instead blames Democrats for failing to negotiate a spending deal, citing political agendas over food security. A $6 billion contingency fund is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits, and 17 states have paused new applications due to the inability to issue partial payments. While WIC was temporarily saved by a $300 million shift in tariff revenue, that funding cannot support SNAP. Advocacy groups stress that November is especially critical due to the approaching Thanksgiving holiday, and food pantries are already overwhelmed. Critics, including New York Governor Kathy Hochul, have condemned the administration’s actions as deliberate and harmful to vulnerable families. This marks a recurring crisis in food assistance during government shutdowns, raising urgent questions about the stability of the nation’s social safety net.
title: Millions of Americans Are at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Next Month Amid Shutdown
